oslo_concurrency/lockutils.py.message:
I think that it's better to set this to `False`. We will avoid unexpected behaviour after lib upgrade. Explicit is better than implicit.

Maybe we could switch to `True` within future openstack series before a "deprecation" period of the default value, to let's users acknowledging these changes and so allowing them to adapt their codes.

Thoughts?
Indeed, it is precisely to keep the default behavior.

It already defaults to True: https://github.com/harlowja/fasteners/blob/e1764c7c2827a8aef0b0a547fb88a9f576adbe81/fasteners/process_lock.py#L109

This is just exposing an option provided by fasteners.

I don't love that there's going to be a "released" message even if we never acquired the lock. Maybe we change the behavior here so that if t2 is None we don't log the release? I'm not sure why it was implemented this way in the first place, but if we never got the lock then the log message doesn't make sense.
Could we get a versionchanged line here indicating the new parameter? We probably want one for 'fair' also since that was missed initially

oslo_concurrency/tests/unit/test_lockuti.message:
It would be good to have a test where the lock times out too.

That raises another question: Does the blocking parameter have any effect if we don't also expose the timeout paramater? timeout defaults to None, so I'm thinking that even if we set blocking to False it may wait forever because there's no timeout.

Hello,

According to the documentation of the lock modules, the timeout parameter has not effect when using non-blocking Locks:

Process locks (fasteners.InterProcessLock) just ignore this parameter and give up on the first acquisition failure without waiting. Thread locks (Python threading.Lock) forbid it outright (https://docs.python.org/3/library/threading.html#lock-objects).

I checked: it works. Do I always add these tests to make sure?

Kind regards

build-tools/stx/dsc_depend.py.message:
Not sure what debian packages are like, but centos was littered with dependency cycles.  Simply giving up was not an option.  

On factor to break cycles, allow the use of unmodified upstream binary packages to satisfy the dependencies.  Target packages that are unlikely to change behavior or affect output, like a scripting language.  e.g. X dep on Y dep on BASH dep on X.  Use upstream BASH, build Y, build X, build BASH.

I don't think you can just give up like that.  The cycles are real. They aren't bugs that the engineer can make go away by falsifying the build dependencies within a dsc.  At some point we have to provide a set of foundational packages from upstream that allow you to bootstrap a build environment and break the cycle.  And this tool needs to be aware of the packages in that foundational package set... probably in the form of a config file providing a list binary packages that can be used as alternative sources to break the cycle.

Yes, just like you said above, Debian also has such cases, so we try to detect it and let engineer to deal with it manually, case by case. This module can't deal with it by itself, so once cycle dependent is detected, it can only raise exceptions and let engineer make it manually.
appears to use self.wait_on before it has been initialized
I will init it just after the "self.depend_by" in V2.

why 10 rather than 1 ?

Or you might want to set an initial priority based in package size (a crude proxy for expected compile time).  The later might be valuable if parallel package builds are supported, and you want to prioritize dependency chains that are slowest to build over those that are deepest.  I found that this kept more build engines busy, and improved over all build times significantly.

Yes, set to 10 instead of 1 is just a prepare for later optimization. :-)
Till now, no such requirement yet but once we get such requirement(soon or later), it will be easy to make it.
And, thanks for your kindly remind about the parallel build.
I'd like to see this captured as a story/task

The "wait_on" here is reasonable. In this process, the dictionary "wait_on" will never changed, while tmp_d_by/on here is used to simulate the build process and we calculate the priority in the process. Use "wait_on" here mean: I don't care how many packages been remove, I just use the original dependent relationships. :-)

BTW: seems machine language is more fit for such cases, I tried to log it with natural language but find it is fairly harder. 😞
ok, I'm still not clean on how self.wait_on is populated with real data prior to it being used here.  All you added above was an initialization as the empty set.
Yes, I missed it. Great thanks for your remind!

README.md.message: "... for nova-compute units."  The scope of queries is whenever the cloud-compute relation changes, not just due to deployment.

Just as a note, the "distro" value is the most common.  i.e. the LTS version of ubuntu AND OpenStack is 'distro' which is why it is the default.  The UCA value is to pick something that isn't the LTS version.
This is a boilerplate chunk of text that has been around for a while. I think it's OK since 'distro' is the default which means this option would not be used.
I would change this to 'distro'.  i.e. leave it as the LTS version.
I'm providing an example of using this option, which is typically only used when using a UCA release.

The use of the word "preferred" makes it seem that os-*-network options are the better ones to use (i.e. 'preferred').  It's actually that they are 'legacy' and will still work if they are set.  It's preferred that they are not used at all.  I think it should say something like:

Existing deployments using the legacy `os-*-network` configuration options will continue to function; if set, the `os-*-option` take priority over any network space bindings provided.  New deployments should avoid using the `os-*-network` options where possible.
Thank you, I'll save these remarks for the Spaces documentation effort. As I mention in the commit message, I've deliberately avoided updating this section with the exception of minor formatting.

I'd just remove this sentence, or just say something like: "Caching SSH known hosts reduces 'cloud-compute' hook execution time."  i.e. don't just link it to deployment; it's to do with the whole lifecycle of the charm. Suggested text:

Specifies a space-separated list of devices to use for LVM physical volumes. This is a mandatory option. Value types include:

* block devices (e.g. 'sdb' or '/dev/sdb')

* a path to a local file with the size appended after a pipe (e.g. '/path/to/file|10G'). The file will be created if necessary and be mapped to a loopback device. This is intended for development and testing purposes. The default size is 5G.

To prevent potential data loss an already formatted device (or one containing LVM metadata) cannot be used unless the `overwrite` configuration option is set to 'true'.

==

I based much of this on the `block-device` option in the swift-storage charm.
Ack
Shouldn't this be managed by the cinder charm?

Indeed it is something that can happen (At least, as far as I understand). I don't know if it's something that we should warn again, to honest. In my opinion, it's something that _may_ be useful, but it depends on each particular charm. With cinder, since it lends to various "plugins", I think it works OK as long as the user doesn't go overboard by overriding options.

This option only allows specifying additional config options to the cinder backend section for the subordinate, not generally overriding the values provided by the cinder charm. The cinder charm has config-flags options which allows specifying additional key/value settings in the [DEFAULT] section for cinder.conf, while this config-flag option allows specifying additional key/value settings for the specific backend section. In other words, it does not allow for the scenario that you are describing where a subordinate can override the principle charm settings.

Can we guide the user a little by providing examples of pertinent settings ("config flags")? Out of curiosity, what happens if a provided setting does not pertain to the LVM backend? What happens if a pertinent setting is misspelled? Does the charm perform input checking?

Doesn't this give us a situation where one charm can clobber the configuration of another? I believe that this is an issue with charms in general but shouldn't we try to avoid that when possible (i.e. only pass native Cinder options via the cinder charm)?

The settings will get set key=value as defined in the cinder.conf file, however if they are not understood by Cinder then the key will be ignored and not take effect.

@Luciano - the debug or verbosity flags cannot be set in the DEFAULT section with these options as they are limited to the section defined for the cinder backend. i.e. if you specified debug=True as an option for cinder-foobar then you'd get the following, which would have no effect.

[cinder-foobar]
debug=True

Other charms don't specify in detail some of the options that are available for configuration as the config-flags option is seen as a work around to having options correctly defined ore modeled. The idea being that we would like to understand the use case and set the values appropriately, according to the use case.

cinder-lvm doesn't perform any input checking other than verifying that the parameter "config-flags" is a comma-separated string with the form "key=value".

It can be used to, for example, modify "debug" or "verbosity" flags in the DEFAULT section of the cinder configuration file.
This option allows cinder-lvm to pass additional configuration options back into cinder.
Interesting, I didn't know that. Thanks, Billy.
I would omit this option as it is not "a common and/or important one".
Ack

Permits ('true') the charm to attempt to overwrite storage devices (specified by the `block-devices` option) if they contain pre-existing filesystems or LVM metadata. The default is 'false'. A device in use on the host will never be overwritten.

src/tests/bundles/bionic-rocky.yaml.message: doesn't this cause the cinder charm to create an lvm configuration?

It doesn't appear to be doing that. Even though both charms have the same block-device configured, they can coexist.

Regarding the upgrade note, I've created a bug to address that specifically, after talking to Peter about upgrade paths: https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1945249

The cinder charm will only create the physical volume, but the volume creation will be delegated completely to cinder-lvm. This block-device parameter was added because on the bionic series cinder did require an actual device IIRC. In other bundles it was set to None.

I'm unclear on what, if any, work will be done on the cinder charm as a consequence of the cinder-lvm charm but the cinder charm currently has '/dev/sdb' as a default for option `block-device`, rendering that device unavailable to the cinder-lvm charm. Shouldn't we at least change that to NULL?
It does. cinder will create a 'cinder-volumes' PV, but it doesn't disturb what cinder-lvm does (because of the alias, cinder-lvm will use a different name).

nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py.message: You need to remove the model the release before you delete the table. I think you can go ahead and do that if you've eliminated every possible way to get there, right?

Same comment from the previous set. Is there some reason you're not removing the models now? Because we won't be able to drop the tables in X if we don't. If all the code that hits them is gone in this release, there's really no reason to keep them, AFAIK. Somewhere in the model sync test there's a list you can add these to so it doesn't complain about them being missing.

I've previously attempted to do this [1] but it's still not entirely clear to me how this should be achieved. [1] suggests that I should drop the table first. If it's okay with you, I'd rather tackle this separately via a follow-up. There are loads of models to be cleaned up here.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/698706
Okay, let's do that so. I'm going to keep it separate because I also have a load of other models to drop at the same time and I might as well do them in one go (same whitelist needed for all)

If you look at my last comment on that patch, it kinda explains the point. If you remove the models now, then you can drop the schema later knowing that every use of it is gone in the previous release. However, in that patch's case you were asserting that they were *already* completely unused and wanted to do both in the same cycle, which is why we had you put the schema drop before the model drop to prove it. It's just cleaner and clearer to drop the models when you drop the use of them (IMHO) so that next cycle it's obvious that the schema is unreachable by both the N-1 release we have to support, along with the N release in which you're doing it.

I don't really care if you do it in this patch or a follow-on (although I'm not sure why you would want to make it two patches).

gbpservice/neutron/plugins/ml2plus/drive.message:
I think you could replace the multiple queries with one query. Something like:

    # Get a list of (port, HA IP) tuple objects that appear in both
    # in the Port and HA IP tables
    port_and_haip_dbs = session.query(models_v2.Port,
        HAIPAddressToPortAssociation).join(HAIPAddressToPortAssociation,
            HAIPAddressToPortAssociation.port_id == models_v2.Port.id)
    net_to_ha_ip_dict = {}
    # Iterate across the list of tuples to build the dictionary of
    # HA IPs, whose network ID is the key, and whose value is another
    # dictionary with a key of the HA IP, and the value is the list of
    # HA IP DB objects
    for port_db, haip_db in port_and_haip_dbs:
        ha_ip_dict = net_to_ha_ip_dict.setdefault(port_db.network_id, {})
        ha_ip_dict[haip_db['ha_ip_address']].append(haip_db)

    # Go through the dictionary and delete any cases where there is
    # more than one port for a given HA IP on a given network.
    for haip_dict in net_to_ha_ip_dict:
        for ha_ip in haip_dict.keys():
            if len(haip_dict[ha_ip]) > 1:
                for haip_db in haip_dict[ha_ip]
                    session.delete(haip_db)

manifests/keystone/auth.pp.message: you can just use the spaceship operator instead of doing an if clase.  Keystone_endpoint<| name == .. |> ~> Anchor['barbican::service::end']

That's true and looks a better idea but I prefer keeping the current implementation, because the same logic using if {} is already implemented in several modules.

In the future we can replace these dependency definitions by the spaceship operator but IMO that should be done in a consistent manner in all modules.
